content.explanation:
Function notation is mathematical shorthand that makes everything clearer!

Instead of writing: 'y equals 2 times x plus 3'
We write: f(x) = 2x + 3

üî§ f(x) is read as 'f of x'
‚ùå NOT 'f times x'
‚úÖ It means 'the output when the input is x'

You can use any letter: f(x), g(x), h(x), C(t), etc. The letter often relates to what the function represents (C for cost, h for height, etc.).
content.example:
üì± If C(h) = 10 + 5h represents phone bill cost:
‚Ä¢ C(0) = $10 (0 hours of calls)
‚Ä¢ C(3) = $25 (3 hours of calls)
‚Ä¢ C(h) = 40 means you used 6 hours
content.key_point: f(x) is a compact way to say 'function f applied to input x'.
